column1: I like how the Wolves are starting Josh Okogie, a 6'4" guy who isn't a threat on offense at all (although he does have a 7' wingspan) at power forward because they're so void of defense at the 4.  Aaron Gordon would look immaculate on this team man.

This feels like a pretty gross overstatement. The Wolves are not just missing KAT. They were missing 3 front-court players.  They’re already one of the smaller teams in the league and are missing their top 2 centers. They were forced to start their 3rd string center and the 6’4” Josh Okogie at PF. Their backup PF who weighs 214 pounds served as the backup center and had to guard Embiid despite giving up probably around 100 pounds.   While neither KAT nor Naz are going to shut Embiid down, they definitely aren’t going to get absolutely steamrolled like Vanderbilt who’s built more like a 3 than a 5. While I don’t think Embiid is getting shut down by many players, most teams at least have 1 or 2 legitimate center sized guys to throw at him.   Also, Embiid benefits greatly from the improved spacing of the modern game (especially now that the Sixers have some) and the way it’s led to more small-ball. Don’t get me wrong, he’s a fantastic player. But he’s not in Shaq’s league as an offensive player. Shit, teams brought in 7 foot 270 pounds stiffs just to throw fouls at Shaq. If Shaq was matched up against a team with no one over 6’9” and whose second heaviest player was their 19 years old SG, he’d have dropped 50.

There was a stretch in that game where the warriors just decided not to guard Josh Okogie and he just bricked like 4 or 5 threes in a row in consecutive possessions. Honestly felt really bad for him. I like him as a player.   Also, hope Naz Reid is okay, love his game.

Don't worry, they got the warriors tomorrow which means expect any player in a shooting slump to turn into prime Klay Thompson from 3 (except for poor Josh Okogie today) and for every big man to turn into Dennis Rodman on the boards.

Now he has COVID. All this constant on and off will always makes things difficult. My point was that people that only watched Covington whenever he played their team or in highlights only thought of him as the second coming of Dennis Rodman because he was a prominent piece on his team's defense.  His last full year in Philly he was guarding the top wing scorer a lot of time cause Ben wasn't Ben yet (defensively). Then he went to the Wolves and continued getting the top wing assignment because who else would? Andrew Wiggins or rookie Josh Okogie? Then the Rockets traded away a first in a confusing 4-way deal where he was the main piece they were getting back. And continued getting the top wing assignment because Harden definitely isn't the one to get it. Then the Blazers traded two firsts for him.  If you're an NBA fan that just hasn't watched enough Covington analysis you 100% think he's some defensive guru based on the fact that he always gets the top wing assignment wherever he ends up playing for and the fact that teams trade away picks for him every deadline without him being a good scorer

>VIII) The easy fixes for Anthony Edwards  I continue to be bullish on Edwards. His growing chemistry with Karl-Anthony Towns has been one of the joys of the past two months -- how they bob and weave in concert, faking a handoff one way before flipping it the other direction. The return of D'Angelo Russell has interrupted that development a tad, but talent is talent, and the Wolves need all they can get.  Minnesota is 6-6 with Russell and Towns available. Josh Okogie rediscovered his confidence from deep, though we know how that movie usually ends. Jaden McDaniels is legit; the Okogie/McDaniels pairing is the type of defensive bulwark the Russell/Edwards/Towns nucleus needs, though I'm skeptical it brings enough shooting.  Meanwhile, Malik Beasley and his 20 points per game are missing; the Russell/Beasley/Towns/Edwards quartet has logged just 13 minutes. Such bad luck could only befall the Wolves.  Minus his nightly steal, Edwards has been bad on defense -- as expected for a teenager. It takes time for score-first guys to learn the complexities of NBA schemes. Barring some lack of will, Edwards should become at least an average defender.  He can start with the low-hanging fruit of transition defense. Minnesota is as bad there as the Kings, and way worse with Edwards on the floor -- in both volume of transition chances and opponent efficiency, per Cleaning The Glass data.  Edwards can be slow to realize when he should ditch his matchup and take the closest opposing player:  He sometimes meanders toward the offensive glass -- too halfhearted to count as "crashing" -- when he has little chance at a rebound. Edwards has 47 offensive rebounds in 60 games, so the risk-reward is not working.  Ambling cuts to nowhere can undo Minnesota's floor balance:  Edwards has good intentions: making himself available for the corner-to-corner pass. But Naz Reid -- having a very nice season! -- is already there, with two other Wolves under the basket.  This is fixable with experience and care. If we are having this same discussion in two years, it's a problem.

**Staying tier:**  KAT  D'lo   Ant   Jaden McDaniels   Naz Reid   **Maybe tier:**  Malik Beasley  Josh Okogie  Jarred Vanderbilt  Jaylen Nowell  Juancho Hernangomez  **Leaving tier:**  Rubio  Culver  Jake Layman  Ed Davis  Jordan McLaughlin

You almost have to throw the advanced numbers out when evaluating this Wolves team due to injuries and the resulting lineups it resulted in.   KAT missed 22 games. Russell missed 30. Beasley missed 35. That sometimes meant guys like Ant had to play alongside some BAD teammates in some BAD lineups. This was especially apparent early (when KAT missed time), when Ant was coming off the bench. There were tons of games where Ant was asked to lead a second unit of Jordan McLaughlin-Josh Okogie-Jarred Vanderbilt-Naz Reid. That meant he was either jacking up contested 3s or driving into a jam-packed paint. There were numerous games where he was something like 4-18 and it wasn’t because he was just jacking shots. The Wolves before the break were PAINFUL (they had the worst record in the entire league for a reason). Because Edwards didn’t miss any time and was there for all of those god ugly days, he’s naturally going to have a gnarly set of advanced statistics.

I don’t know about the whole NBA, but on the Timberwolves it’s Jaden McDaniels.  After a slow rookie start, he shot .383 from 3 with a .600 TS%.  He was the best defensive player on our team, and that’s saying something with Josh Okogie.     He was a top 5 rookie post all star and is going to be a 3&D menace for the next 15 years and people are acting like he’s a nothing bench prospect.  Every Wolves fan has him pencilled in as our long term starter without any hesitation.
Offense: D'Angelo Russell, Malik Beasley, Anthony Edwards, Juancho Hernangomez, KAT.  Defense: Ricky Rubio, Jarrett Culver, Josh Okogie, Jaden McDaniels, Jarred Vanderbilt.

The argument about the franchise being shitty and it affecting development of young players usually comes from people who know nothing about Timberwolves. Yes, we are perennial suckers and yes, we frequently draft busts in the lottery. However, with the new management (since 2019) we have drafted (or signed as undrafted FA) and played Naz Reid, Jaylen Nowell, Jaden McDaniels, Anthony Edwards, and Jarrett Culver. [We also drafted Bolmaro but we are yet to see his development in the team]. ALL of them have shown a development to some extend and all of them are way better players/assets than Culver.   Culver was given all the chances in the world. We even started him at PG during the rookie season. He was below average in his first season, however with some promise. He worked hard over the summer and came to the training camp in a decent shape, impressed the fans during the preseason games. He started last season as 6-7 man in the rotation. The team started to suck right away after KAT got injured, and Culver even started for some games. He has shown NOTHING. He cannot shoot, cannot be a playmaker, cannot finish with contact. His defense is mediocre at best, Okogie is a way better defender than him.   Culver reminds me of a poor man version of Josh Hart who has a similar skillset but does everything worse. I feel like Josh Hart is his ceiling if he really works hard and figures it out. At this point, Im very glad Timberwolves dont have to make a decision about picking up his option for the next year - paying 14+ mil to Culver in the next 2 years could have been a problem. I hopes he at least can play in the summer league, but he got injured at the end of the last season and did not recover. Wish him all the best, but not in Timberwolves uniform.

We couldnt have 4 bench guys all incapable of scoring. And thats why Jaden McDaniels and Jaylen Nowell both got chances ahead of him

Yup. Most of the really good defensive guards have a crazy wingspan. Makes contesting shots and getting deflections that much easier.   Josh Okogie has a 7'0 wingspan, but is only 6'4. Reggie Jackson is 6'3 with a 7'0 wingspan. Jrue Holiday is 6'3 with a 6'7 wingspan. Etc.

>Lavine was a tiny fraction of what he is now in Minnesota. You’re purely speculating that his time there played any role in what he became. I’ll give you the benefit of the doubt regarding Lavines playmaking but that’s probably the worst aspect of his game outside of his defence so it doesn’t influence how good he is for the most part. His playmaking is also largely just passing out of doubles.  He was averaging 18.9 ppg before he went down with his injury and was clearly on the trajectory to be where he is now. He was empowered to be the #1 option in Chicago which certainly helped but to act like what he did in Minnesota is a tiny fraction of his development is a laughable take.  >The issue is basically every athletic fringe rotational player is a good defender. Defence is largely based on effort and players who are fighting for minutes will often provide the most effort. What makes defenders stand out is impact and okogie is not an impactful defender. Wings and guards are less impactful as is, so you generally have to be like an all defence guy, or have some offence too.  Not every "athletic fringe rotation player" is a good defender because you can't teach motor and instincts and Okogie is certainly an impactful defender because of his giant wingspan that allows him to play SF and in certain lineups to guard PF's. Try watching Josh play sometime?

I see what you're saying there. I would say that with the amount of close games we have been in this year, the hope is that a coach who is adapting to the game and making proper adjustments is able to put us in better positions to win. And/or to hold the players more accountable for their mistakes.  An example from this year alone is playing Rubio and Dlo together so often, especially at the end of games. Both guards need the ball in their hand to be successful. The issue is when you are putting the ball in dlo hands, that is essentially making Rubio a shooting guard. He is having a terrible year from 3, which opponents take advantage of. Same issue playing Josh Okogie so often when teams are able to literally leave him wide open.  I'm all for a coach believing in their players, but the coach also has to have the ability to look outside of their personal relationship with the player and making decisions that put the team in the best scenario to win.  If the new coach is able to make these adjustments and adapt to each game, while also installing an offense that sets up and runs plays, I will personally be very happy.
